Predictions have been made that a rough equivalence will be achieved around 2030 in the number of synapses vs. transistors. But it doesn't work like that, the human brain is three dimensional in it's connections and uses both chemical and electrical processes. So you see, the computer is just a simple brute capable of huge numbers of calculations. It won't be able to achieve intelligence since all of it's actions can be modeled. Humans are much more unpredictable. But who knows what'll happen :)

@Stonehawk Case in point, in 2001: Facebook, Twitter, Youtube, Reddit, and even 4CHAN didn't exist yet! Google was JUST becoming popular in the mainstream, and Wikipedia ITSELF had only just forked off of the now-long-dead Nupedia project, and Craigslist had only just begun to expand into cities other than its original home, San Francisco; Paypal -became- publicly tradable as a corporate entity in 2001 as well. We're certainly well on our way, aren't we?

@1Jikko1 Not crazy at all, Jikko! The concept of a global, instantaneously real-time, electronic audio-visual communications network that absolutely everybody can access is *still* bewildering to a big chunk of the population alive today! I talk to a loooot of senior citizens at my job, bless their hearts, and they tell me on a nearly daily basis! Even now, the rate is, ITSELF, accelerating! Most of what we know and love about the internet today wasn't even around as little as ten years ago!

@1stParadoxStudio There's actually quite a bit of oxygen-rich ore on the moon; and using solar power, it could be relatively easily and consistently extracted, processed, and recycled. The greenhouses that would supply food would also convert carbon dioxide back into oxygen. A colony would be much better at this than a single structure like the International Space Station; there's a critical threshold of useful interior space one needs before it can self-sustain, and it's possible on the moon.
